Description: Terracotta male figure carrying wreath and jar. Mould-made. The upper part of a standing man, a celebrant, wearing a short belted skirt and a bulla on a chain round his neck. His hair recedes over his forehead and he has a tightly woven wreath. A large, separately made phallus was inserted in a hole in the appropriate place, but only a stump remains, fixed in place by plaster. He holds against his left shoulder an Egyptian amphora, with a smooth body, a ribbed neck and a rounded seal. In his lowered right hand he has a looped garland. The back is summarily treated, only the skirt being well indicated. At the nape of the neck is a suspension-loop, probably showing that the figure had no plinth. Both the figure and the inserted phallus were made in two-piece moulds; they are hollow. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt with a dark-brown core. There are a few traces of an overall white dressing, with pink paint on the wreath, the chain of the bulla, the neck of the amphora and behind the lower right arm.
Curator's comments: Similar parallels dated second half of second century AD (Bayer-Niemeier 1988, no. 209; and Graindor 1939, pl. 23, 64). Registered in same series as Naukratis objects. Bayer-Niemeier, E. 1988, Bildwerke der Sammlung Kaufmann / Liebieghaus Museum Alter Plastik Frankfurt am Main I. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten, Melsungen. Graindor, P. 1939, Terres cuites de l’Égypte gréco-romaine, Antwerp.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3179)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.594) (Phase 3)
Condition: His left leg is lost from the top of the thigh, his right from the knee.
